metadata.sermon_start_end: I want to offer you some instruction in evangelical geography, that is, reflection on how the good news is always context specific. In Mark 6:30–44 Jesus does his well-known feeding of 5,000. Remember that number, six! In 6:1, he is in Nazareth and after that he is “among the villages,” all in Galilee. [...] God is the giver of many baskets of well-being, all that rich surplus that leads to well-being. This requires a gospel voice that recognizes that geography is not destiny. It is rather a matrix of abundance that depends on thanks and brokenness. Imagine, both in Galilee among Jews and in the Decapolis among Greeks, he took, he blessed, he broke, he gave. He still does!

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails to focus on one specific Bible passage. It treats three distinct chapters of Mark as a thematic trajectory. This violates Dekker's rule that a sermon is not about a 'biblical idea' or 'keyword' (geography), but the unique content of one pericope. By spanning chapters 6, 7, and 8, the preacher provides a general overview rather than the specific depth of one text.
quotes: In Mark 6:30–44 Jesus does his well-known feeding of 5,000.
At the end of chapter 7, we are told...
And then, in chapter 8, there was again a crowd of hungry people.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select either the feeding of the 5,000 or the Syrophoenician woman. Focus exclusively on the unique details of that specific text that can be found nowhere else.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The preacher shows adequate knowledge of the socio-religious context (Galilee vs. Decapolis, purity laws). However, the exegesis is used to serve a pre-conceived thematic 'geography' rather than letting the text's own theological weight speak. The claim that Jesus was 'reeducated' or 'converted' by the woman is a specific exegetical choice that borders on dogmatic imposition.
quotes: The Decapolis consists in ten cities that were built and inhabited by Greeks.
Jesus is still embedded in the purity laws... He is a Jew and had not thought beyond his own Jewishness.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Avoid psychologizing Jesus' inner development ('he had not thought beyond...') and focus more on the linguistic and theological nuances of the Greek text itself.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is very concrete, specifically identifying the city of Louisville and its socio-economic divisions. This aligns with Dekker's demand for 'true truth' being concrete. However, it leans heavily toward 'being lost in time' (social/political) at the expense of the 'eternal' or 'individual' dimension.
quotes: Imagine that the city of Louisville is divided into two zones...
And imagine that there is another zone of Louisville, out west.
The future of West Louisville will be as a recipient of abundance.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Balance the socio-political application with the spiritual and individual reality of the hearer's standing before God.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a 'lecturing' structure: I, II, III, IV are exposition, and V is application. This is exactly what Dekker warns against as making the relevance unclear until the end. The hearer is not 'drawn into the text' in one movement but is given a history lesson followed by a contemporary comparison.
quotes: So here is the geography lesson of an evangelical kind.
So consider this evangelical geography and how it might be narrated in Louisville.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Integrate the Louisville context directly into the reading of the Markan text so that exposition and application happen simultaneously.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon focuses almost exclusively on 'misery' (social disadvantage) and 'redemption' (social redistribution). However, 'misery' is defined as socio-economic lack rather than misery 'before God'. The 'gratitude' part is largely missing, replaced by a call for social justice.
quotes: That zone is regarded by the leading opinion makers in the city as impure, unworthy...
It is time to move the festival of abundance from the zone of privilege to the zone of disadvantage.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the definition of misery to include the spiritual poverty of both the 'privileged' and 'disadvantaged' before God.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The 'two ways' are present only in a horizontal, political sense (privilege vs. disadvantage). There is no mention of the ultimate possibility of being lost eternally or the seriousness of the individual's response to God's calling beyond social activism.
quotes: Imagine that the city of Louisville is divided into two zones...
Martin would join us in the redistribution of bread.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the hearer as a 'willing and responsible being' regarding their eternal destination, not just their social location.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the subject, but he is portrayed more as a student of the Syrophoenician woman than as the 'One Lord' who is God. The 'telos' of the sermon is social redistribution rather than the person of Christ as our life outside ourselves. Grace is equated with 'abundance' and 'well-being' rather than the justification of the sinner.
quotes: Jesus exhibits his conversion by promptly going to the Decapolis.
This Jewish rabbi, perceived to be the Messiah, has to reach out to the others.
God is the giver of many baskets of well-being.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Re-establish Christ as the divine Lord (two natures) whose grace is the 'deepest of our life' beyond material well-being.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 18.5 minutes, the sermon falls slightly short of Dekker's 20-minute minimum. While it has 'breadth' in its geographical scope, it lacks the 'depth' of a single-passage exposition.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical depth of a single passage to reach the 20-minute mark.

overall_assessment.summary: The text functions more as a thematic lecture on social justice than a sermon as defined by Dekker. It lacks a specific biblical anchor, choosing instead to weave a narrative across three chapters. The Christology is problematic, presenting a 'converted' Jesus who learns from a human, which undermines the 'One Lord' as the telos. The application is concrete but strictly horizontal.
strengths: Concrete application to the specific city (Louisville) avoids generalities.
Clear identification of the socio-political 'purity laws' in modern society.
Strong narrative flow that maintains engagement.
weaknesses: Lack of focus on a single, specific pericope.
Separation of exposition and application into distinct blocks.
Reduction of 'misery' and 'redemption' to socio-economic categories.
Absence of the 'two ways' in an eternal or individual sense.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the strict sense of Dekker's theses. It is a 'speech about a biblical idea' (geography/inclusion) rather than an 'actualization of a specific Bible passage.' It prioritizes cultural philosophy over the proclamatory Word of God.
